objects.name: Attack Flow
objects.description: Extends STIX 2.1 with features to create Attack Flows.

external_references.description: Source code repository for Attack Flow

objects.name: MITRE Engenuity Center for Threat-Informed Defense
Gootloader
objects.description: Attack flow on the Gootloader payload distribution attack.
author: name
Mia Sanchez
identity_class
23b79ae0fc0f07a3669598dd23c694cc

objects.name: Drive-by Compromise
objects.description: The user searched for results and clicked on a compromised website. After navigating to the compromised website, a forum-looking page was displayed and the user clicked on a link, which downloaded a file
Attackers launched Search Engine Optimization (SEO) poisoning attack - moves compromised websites hosting malware to top of search requests

objects.name: Compromise Infrastructure
objects.description: Attackers compromised websites to host malware

objects.name: User Execution: Malicious File
objects.description: The user double clicked on the dropped zip file
Malicious file downloaded

objects.name: Command and Scripting Interpreter: JavaScript
objects.description: User double-clicks Javascript file, located within zip, to execute
Zip file opened

objects.name: Modify Registry
objects.description: Gootloader creates two registry keys, the first is populated with an encoded Cobalt Strike payload and the latter stores a .NET loader

objects.name: powershell.dll
objects.description: .NET loader

objects.name: Command and Scripting Interpreter: PowerShell
objects.description: A PowerShell command is issued to extract the .NET loader from the registry and executes the code in memory via Assembly.Load()

objects.name: Scheduled Task/Job
objects.description: The encoded PowerShell script creates a Scheduled Task that executes when the user logs on to the computer.

objects.name: System Binary Proxy Execution: Rundll32
objects.description: .NET loader decodes a Cobalt Strike payload from the registry and loads and executes the payload

objects.name: rundll32
objects.description: Often used to load the Cobalt Strike beacons into memory on the victim machine

objects.name: Account Discovery
objects.description: The threat actors used Bloodhound on the initial victim computer to enumerate the Active Directory domain

objects.name: Domain Trust Discovery
objects.description: The threat actors used Bloodhound on the initial victim computer to enumerate the Active Directory domain

objects.name: Group Policy Discovery
objects.description: The threat actors used Bloodhound on the initial victim computer to enumerate the Active Directory domain
Enumerated AD Domain information

objects.name: Command and Scripting Interpreter: PowerShell
objects.description: The attackers then pivoted to nearby workstation host via a Cobalt Strike Powershell beacon

objects.name: Windows Management Instrumentation/Software Discovery: Security Software Discovery
objects.description: WMI used to check for AV software on the 2 compromised computers

objects.name: Impair Defenses: Disable or Modify Tools
objects.description: Attackers disabled Windows Defender logs on the Workstation

objects.name: Command and Scripting Interpreter
objects.description: A second Cobalt Strike payload is deployed on the workstation to initiate a second C2 server

objects.name: C2 server
objects.description: deployed on the workstation through a Cobalt Strike payload

objects.name: Command and Scripting Interpreter: PowerShell
objects.description: The malicious PowerShell process used by Gootloader dropped a PowerShell script on the file system.

objects.name: Workstation
objects.description: second victim on the network after the initial victim
Workstation compromised

objects.name: Command and Scripting Interpreter: PowerShell
objects.description: Another PowerShell command triggers the mi.ps1 script on the initial victim's computer to harvest credentials

objects.name: mi.ps1
objects.description: output lists "Invoke-Mimikatz"; a renamed version of Mimikatz

objects.name: Credentials from Password Stores
objects.description: The threat actors then ran LaZagne to retrieve all saved credentials from the workstation

objects.name: ls.exe
objects.description: renamed LaZagne; dumps passwords and stores the output file; with admin privileges, it can dump credentials from registry hives

objects.name: Remote Services: Windows Remote Management
objects.description: The attackers enabled Restricted Admin Mode through remote WMI. This was allowed because RAM only requires knowledge of the password hash, not the cleartext password

objects.name: Remote Services: Remote Desktop Protocol
objects.description: Using the harvested credentials, the threat actors used RDP to move from the initial victim computer to the compromised workstation in restricted admin mode.

objects.name: Impair Defenses: Disable or Modify Tools
objects.description: Microsoft Defender Scheduled Tasks Deleted

objects.name: Remote Services: SMB/Windows Admin Shares
objects.description: SMB was used to transfer Cobalt Strike payload executables to 3 additional workstations.
Attackers attempted to move laterally by targeting 3 additional workstations
Attackers compromised 3 additional workstations

objects.name: Remote Services: Windows Remote Management
objects.description: The attackers enabled Restricted Admin Mode via remote WMI

objects.name: Remote Services: Remote Desktop Protocol
objects.description: The attackers logged into the Domain Controller through RDP

objects.name: Command and Scripting Interpreter: PowerShell
objects.description: PowerShell used to execute Cobalt Strike PowerShell payload

objects.name: Impair Defenses: Disable or Modify Tools
objects.description: Microsoft Defender Scheduled Tasks Deleted

objects.name: Credentials from Password Stores
objects.description: LaZagne dropped and executed

objects.name: Data from Network Shared Drive
objects.description: The attackers then accessed documents on the file share server interactively through wordpad.exe from the initial victim's computer

objects.name: Remote Services: Remote Desktop Protocol
objects.description: The attackers logged into the File Share Server through RDP from the initial victim's computer

objects.name: Command and Scripting Interpreter: PowerShell
objects.description: PowerShell used to execute Cobalt Strike PowerShell payload

objects.name: Impair Defenses: Disable or Modify Tools
objects.description: Microsoft Defender Scheduled Tasks Deleted

objects.name: Remote Services: Windows Remote Management
objects.description: The attackers enabled Restricted Admin Mode via remote WMI
Attackers enumerated and opened multiple files and file shares

objects.name: Network Service Discovery
objects.description: From the Domain Controller, attackers ran an Advanced IP Scanner

objects.name: Data from Network Shared Drive
objects.description: The file server SMB shares were accessed from the Domain Controller

objects.name: Remote Services: Remote Desktop Protocol
objects.description: RDP Connection to Backup Server and File Server to look for more interesting files
Attackers left the network

objects.name: Bloodhound
objects.description: PowerShell implementation of SharpHound that enumerates AD

objects.name: WMI
objects.description: checks for AV software

objects.name: PowerShell
objects.description: Used by attacker to drop additional malware

objects.name: Cobalt Strike beacons
objects.description: payload beacons were dropped to several additional workstations

objects.content: No additional activity was observed on the additional workstations once this lateral movement occurred

objects.name: ls.exe
objects.description: renamed LaZagne; dumps passwords and stores the output file; with admin privileges, it can dump credentials from registry hives
